content_1: . An outbreak of H5N1 in poultry at a village in Lang Son province was reported on June 6. The source of the outbreak is unknown, but 1,008 birds from the village were culled to prevent the spread of the disease. Other preventive measures were set in place, such as quarantine, movement control, and disinfection of the area.
content_2: . Contrary to the recommendations of the steering committee for bird flu, the Government of Pakistan reported on June 7 that it has decided to end the National Programme for the Control and Prevention of Avian Influenza (NPCPAI). NPCPAI had been in charge of prevention and control of bird flu in Pakistan. Based on measures taken under the program, the OIE had declared Pakistan free of bird flu for a period of three months. The program was dismissed through a notification issued by the Adviser to Prime Minister on Dev. Budget Muhammad Asif Shaikh. Some are concerned that due to this decision, Pakistan will not be able to prevent and control the bird flu, will undergo financial and health problems, and the OIE will eventually will not uphold the declaration that Pakistan is a bird flu free country.
content_3: . The Ministry of Health announced a confirmed case of human infection with H5N1 bird flu on June 3. A 1-year-old girl from Jakarta province developed symptoms on April 3, was hospitalized on April 8, and has now fully recovered. One week before the onset of the disease, the patient went with her father to the market and handled chickens while there. Laboratory tests confirmed H5N1 bird flu as the cause of illness. Of the 178 cases confirmed to date in Indonesia, 146 have been fatal.
